sections.answer: Or do you not know that your members are the temple of the Holy Ghost, who is in you, whom you have from God, and that you are not your own? For you have been bought at a great price. Glorify God and bear him in your body. (I Corinthians 6:19-20)

sections.question: How can Catholics best obtain God's blessing for their marriage?
sections.answer: Catholics can best obtain God's blessing for their marriage by being married at a Nuptial Mass and by receiving Holy Communion devoutly. Sara also said, "Have mercy on us, O Lord, have mercy on us; and let us grow old both together in health." (Tobias 8:10) The Sacramentals

sections.question: What are sacramentals?
sections.answer: Sacramentals are holy things or actions of which the Church makes use to obtain for us from God, through her intercession, spiritual and temporal favors. And as Moses lifted up the serpent in the desert, even so must the Son of Man be lifted up, that those who believe in him may not perish, but may have life everlasting. (John 3:14-15)

sections.question: How do the sacramentals obtain favors from God?
sections.answer: The sacramentals obtain favors from God through the prayers of the Church offered for those who make use of them, and through the devotion they inspire.

sections.question: What are the chief benefits obtained by the use of the sacramentals?
sections.answer: The chief benefits obtained by the use of the sacramentals are:

sections.question: actual graces;
the forgiveness of venial sins;
the remission of temporal punishment;
health of body and material blessings;
protection from evil spirits.
Which are the chief kinds of sacramentals?
sections.answer: The chief kinds of sacramentals are: ● blessings given by priests and bishops; ● exorcisms against evil spirits; third, blessed objects of devotion.

sections.question: Which are the blessed objects of devotion most used by Catholics?
sections.answer: The blessed objects of devotion most used by Catholics are: holy water, candles, ashes, palms, crucifixes, medals, rosaries, scapulars, and images of Our Lord, the Blessed Virgin, and the saints. And the whole multitude of the people were praying outside at the hour of incense. (Luke 1:10)

sections.question: How should we make use of sacramentals?
sections.answer: We should make use of the sacramentals with faith and devotion, and never make them objects of superstition. Prayer

sections.question: What is prayer?
sections.answer: Prayer is the lifting up of our minds and hearts to God. Let us lift up our hearts with our hands to the Lord in the heavens. (Lamentations 3:41)

sections.question: Why do we pray?
sections.answer: We pray:

sections.question: to adore God, expressing to Him our love and loyalty;
to thank Him for His favors;
to obtain from Him the pardon of our sins and the remission of their punishment;
to ask for graces and blessings for ourselves and others.
sections.answer: Watch and pray, that you may not enter into temptation. (Matthew 26:41)

sections.question: How should we pray?
sections.answer: We should pray:

sections.question: with attention;
with a conviction of our own helplessness and our dependence upon God;
with a great desire for the graces we beg of Him;
with loving trust in His goodness;
with perseverance.
sections.answer: And all things whatever you ask for in prayer, believing, you shall receive. (Matthew 21:22)

sections.question: For whom should we pray?
sections.answer: We should pray especially for ourselves, for our parents, relatives, friends, and enemies, for sinners, for the souls in purgatory, for the Pope, bishops, and priests of the Church, and for the officials of our country. But I say to you, love your enemies, do good to those who hate you, and pray for those who persecute and calumniate you, so that you may be children of your Father in heaven. (Matthew 5:44-45)

sections.question: How do we know that God always hears our prayers if we pray properly?
sections.answer: We know that God always hears our prayers if we pray properly because Our Lord has promised: "If you ask the Father anything in My name, He will give it to you." And whatever you ask in my name, that I will do, in order that the Father may be glorified in the Son. (John 14:13)

sections.question: Why do we not always obtain what we pray for?
sections.answer: We do not always obtain what we pray for, either because we have not prayed properly or because God sees that what we are asking would not be for our good. You ask and do not receive, because you ask amiss, that you may spend it upon your passions. (James 4:3)

sections.question: Are distractions in our prayers always displeasing to God?
sections.answer: Distractions in our prayers are not displeasing to God, unless they are willful.

sections.question: How many kinds of prayer are there?
sections.answer: There are two kinds of prayer: mental prayer and vocal prayer.

sections.question: What is mental prayer?
sections.answer: Mental prayer is that prayer by which we unite our hearts with God while thinking of His holy truths. For the rest, brethren, whatever things are true, whatever honorable, whatever just, whatever holy, whatever lovable, whatever of good repute, if there be any virtue, if anything worthy of praise, think upon these things. (Philippians 4:8)

sections.question: What is vocal prayer?
sections.answer: Vocal prayer is that prayer which comes from the mind and heart and is spoken by the lips. With my voice I called upon the Lord, and he hearkened to me from his holy mountain. (Psalm 3:5)

sections.question: May we use our own words in praying to God?
sections.answer: We may use our own words in praying to God, and it is well to do so often.

sections.question: What are the prayers that every Catholic should know by heart?
sections.answer: The prayers that every Catholic should know by heart are: the Our Father, the Hail Mary, the Apostles' Creed, the Confiteor, the Glory be to the Father, and the acts of faith, hope, charity, and contrition.

sections.question: How do we usually begin and end our prayers?
sections.answer: We usually begin and end our prayers with the sign of the cross. Go, therefore, and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost. (Matthew 28:19)

sections.question: Why do we make the sign of the cross?
sections.answer: We make the sign of the cross to express two important mysteries of the Christian religion, the Blessed Trinity and the Redemption. And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us. (John 1:14)

sections.question: How are these mysteries expressed by the sign of the cross?
sections.answer: When we say "In the name," we express the truth that there is only one God; when we say "of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost," we express the truth that there are three distinct Persons in God; and when we make the form of the cross on ourselves, we express the truth that the Son of God, made man, redeemed us by His death on the cross. The Our Father

sections.question: Why is the Our Father the best of all prayers?
sections.answer: The Our Father is the best of all prayers because it is the Lord's Prayer, taught us by Jesus Christ Himself, and because it is a prayer of perfect and unselfish love. See Matthew 6:9-13 for the Lord's Prayer.

sections.question: Why is the Our Father a prayer of perfect and unselfish love?
sections.answer: The Our Father is a prayer of perfect and unselfish love because in saying it we offer ourselves entirely to God and ask from Him the best things, not only for ourselves but also for our neighbor.

sections.question: Why do we address God as "Our Father who art in heaven"?
sections.answer: We address God as "Our Father who art in heaven" because we belong to Him, our loving Father, who created us and watches over us, who adopts us through sanctifying grace as His children, and who destines us to live forever with Him in heaven, our true home. In my Father's house, there are many mansions. (John 14:2)

sections.question: For what do we pray when we say "hallowed be Thy name"?
sections.answer: When we say "hallowed be Thy name," we pray that God may be known and honored by all men. From the rising of the sun unto the going down of the same, the name of the Lord is worthy of praise. (Psalm 112:3)

sections.question: For what do we pray when we say "Thy kingdom come"?
sections.answer: When we say "Thy kingdom come," we pray that the kingdom of God's grace may be spread throughout the world, that all men may come to know and to enter the true Church and to live as worthy members of it, and that, finally, we all may be admitted to the kingdom of God's glory. You therefore be perfect, even as your heavenly Father is perfect. (Matthew 5:48)

sections.question: For what do we pray when we say "Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven"?
sections.answer: When we say "Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven," we pray that all men may obey God on earth as willingly as the saints and angels obey Him in heaven. Father, if thou art willing, remove this cup from me; yet not my will but thine be done. (Luke 22:41)

sections.question: For what do we pray when we say "Give us this day our daily bread"?
sections.answer: When we say "Give us this day our daily bread," we pray that God will give us each day all that is necessary to support the material life of our bodies and the spiritual life of our souls. For my flesh is food indeed, and my blood is drink indeed. (John 6:56)

sections.question: For what do we pray when we say "and forgive us our trespasses as we forgive those who
sections.answer: trespass against us"? When we say "and forgive us our trespasses as we forgive those who trespass against us," we pray that God will pardon the sins by which we have offended Him, and we tell Him that we pardon our fellow men who have offended us. For if you forgive men their offenses, your heavenly Father will also forgive you your offenses. But if you do not forgive men, neither will your heavenly Father forgive you your offenses. (Matthew 6:14-15)

sections.question: For what do we pray when we say "and lead us not into temptation"?
sections.answer: When we say "and lead us not into temptation," we pray that God will always give us the grace to overcome the temptations to sin which come to us from the world, the flesh, and the devil. Because thou wast acceptable to God, it was necessary that temptation should prove thee. (Tobias 12:13)

sections.question: For what do we pray when we say "but deliver us from evil"?
sections.answer: When we say "but deliver us from evil," we pray that God will always protect us from harm, and especially from harm to our souls. I do not pray that thou take them out of the world, but that thou keep them from evil. (John 17:15)
